\title[Thermally stable magnetic skyrmions in multilayer SAF racetracks]
{Thermally stable magnetic skyrmions in multilayer synthetic antiferromagnetic racetracks}

\author{Xichao Zhang$^{1,2}$, Motohiko Ezawa$^{3}$ and Yan Zhou$^{1,2}$}
\address{$^{1}$ Department of Physics, University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong, China} 
\address{$^{2}$ School of Electronics Science and Engineering, Nanjing University, Nanjing, China} 
\address{$^{3}$ Department of Applied Physics, University of Tokyo, Hongo 7-3-1, 113-8656, Japan}
\eads{\mailto{ezawa@ap.t.u-tokyo.ac.jp}, \mailto{yanzhou@hku.hk}}

\begin{abstract}
Magnetic skyrmion is a topological magnetization structure with nanometric size and swirling spin distribution, which is anticipated to be an essential building block for novel skyrmionic devices.

We study the motion of magnetic skyrmions in multilayer synthetic antiferromagnetic (SAF) racetracks as well as in a conventional ferromagnetic (FM) monolayer racetrack at finite temperature.

There is an odd-even effect of the constituent FM layer number on the skyrmion Hall effect.

Namely, due to the suppression of the skyrmion Hall effect, the magnetic skyrmions have no transverse motion in SAF racetracks packed with even FM layers.

It is shown that a moving magnetic skyrmion is stable even at room temperature (${\text{T}}=300$ K) in a bilayer SAF racetrack but it is destructed at ${\text{T}}=100$ K in a FM monolayer racetrack.

Our results indicate that the SAF structures are reliable candidates for designing future skyrmion-based spintronic devices.
\end{abstract}

\pacs{75.70.-i, 75.78.-n, 85.70.-w, 85.75.-d}







\vspace{2pc} \noindent\textit{Keywords\/}: skyrmion, skyrmion Hall effect, synthetic antiferromagnet, racetrack memory

\maketitle

\section{Introduction}

A magnetic skyrmion is a nanometric magnetic domain wall structure of which the spin configuration is swirling in the planar space and would wrap a unit three-dimensional spherical surface with spins pointing in all directions in the compactification of the planar space~\cite{Roszler_NATURE2006,Nagaosa_NNANO2013,Bergmann_JPCM2014,Ezawa_QHE2008}.

Recently, experiments have revealed the existence of both N\'eel-type and Bloch-type magnetic skyrmions in thin films as well as bulk materials~\cite{Muhlbauer_SCIENCE2009,Yu_NATURE2010,Heinze_NPHYS2011,Seki_SCIENCE2012,Kezsmarki_NMATER2015,Nahas_NCOMMS2015,Du_NANOLETT2014}.

The spin configuration of a magnetic skyrmion is topologically protected, which is stable as long as it does not overlap tilted spins on the sample edge or shrinks to the lattice scale.

Another merit of magnetic skyrmion is that it can be displaced by spin-polarized current in confined structures.

Thus, a magnetic skyrmion is expected to be a key component of future device applications in the emerging field of skyrmionics~\cite{Fert_NNANO2013,Sampaio_NNANO2013,Iwasaki_NNANO2013,Tomasello_SREP2014,Yan_NCOMMS2014,Xichao_NCOMMS2016,Koshibae_JJAP2015,Xichao_SREP2015B,Yan_NCOMMS2015,Fusheng_NANOLETT2015,Xichao_SREP2015C,Upadhyaya_PRB2015,Beg_SREP2015,Xichao_NANOTECH2015,Sun_PRL2013,Koshibae_NCOMMS2014,Crum_NCOMMS2015}.

Recent experiments have demonstrated the creation, elimination, and manipulation of magnetic skyrmions in confined geometries using cutting-edge technology~\cite{Rimming_SCIENCE2013,Du_NCOMMS2015,Nii_NCOMMS2015,Buttner_NPHYS2015,Wanjun_SCIENCE2015,Woo_ARXIV2015,Finazzi_PRL2013}.

However, one obstacle to the transmission of magnetic skyrmions in confined geometries is the skyrmion Hall effect, where a magnetic skyrmion gain a transverse motion perpendicular to the driving direction~\cite{Zang_PRL2011}.

As a result, the magnetic skyrmion might be destructed when it passes a narrow racetrack-type channel~\cite{Parkin_SCIENCE2008,Parkin_NNANO2015} and/or when it travels at a high speed, by touching the edge~\cite{Xichao_NCOMMS2016,Purnama_SREP2015,Xichao_SREP2015A}.

Recently we have shown~\cite{Xichao_NCOMMS2016} that a magnetic skyrmion moves perfectly straight in the direction of the driving current in a bilayer synthetic antiferromagnetic (SAF) racetrack, where the skyrmion Hall effect is completely suppressed.

The two magnetic skyrmions in the top and bottom ferromagnetic (FM) layers of the bilayer SAF racetrack have the opposite skyrmion numbers, and thus the potential transverse shift directions are opposite and canceled.

Another challenging problem is about the effect of thermal fluctuations, which is detrimental to skyrmion-based devices.

A magnetic skyrmion is largely deformed and might be easily destroyed by thermal fluctuations.

Hence the thermal effect is one of the important factors to realize skyrmionic devices~\cite{Yu_NMATER2011,Yu_NCOMMS2012,Schulz_NPHYS2012,Oike_NPHYS2015}.

In this paper, we study thermal fluctuation effects on the motion of magnetic skyrmions in multilayer SAF racetracks as well as in a FM monolayer racetrack based on numerical simulations and a multilayer Thiele equation.

The magnetic skyrmions in all FM layers of a multilayer SAF racetrack are bounded as one single multilayer skyrmion by the interlayer antiferromagnetic (AFM) exchange coupling.

We call it an $N$-layer skyrmion.

First, we investigate the dynamics of current-driven $N$-layer skyrmions at zero temperature (${\text{T}}=0$ K).

We find the odd-even effect of the number $N$ of constituent FM layers on the skyrmion Hall effect, which is understood as the total skyrmion number of the magnetic skyrmions in each individual FM layer.

Namely, the $N$-layer skyrmion shows the skyrmion Hall effects only when $N$ is odd.

Furthermore, we find that the velocity of the $N$-layer skyrmion at a given driving current density is inversely proportional to $N$ when the driving current is applied only in the bottom FM layer.

We also point out that when the driving current is applied in all FM layers, the velocity of the multilayer skyrmion is basically equal to that of a monolayer skyrmion at a given driving current density.

Second, we investigate the dynamics of the $N$-layer skyrmion at finite temperatures (${\text{T}}>0$ K).

It is shown that the monolayer skyrmion with typical material parameters is destroyed when the temperature is equal to ${\text{T}}=100$ K.

On the other hand, the bilayer skyrmion is stable and goes straight along the bilayer SAF racetrack even at room temperature ${\text{T}}=300$ K.

This is because that the bilayer skyrmion is much more stable than the monolayer skyrmion since two skyrmions consisting the bilayer skyrmion are tightly bounded by the interlayer AFM exchange coupling.

Namely, the thermal fluctuation acts independently between the top and the bottom FM layers, which is almost canceled when the top and bottom skyrmions are tightly bounded.

In general, thermal fluctuation effects decrease rapidly as the layer number $N$ increases.

Our results provide a promising route to realizing skyrmionics at room temperature.


\section{Modeling and simulation}

\subsection{The FM monolayer and SAF racetracks}


Figure~\ref{FIG1} shows the models of the FM monolayer racetrack and the SAF racetracks studied in this paper. The FM monolayer racetrack contains one FM layer and a heavy-metal substrate underneath the FM layer. The $N$-layer SAF racetrack includes $N$ FM layers, which are separated by $N-1$ nonmagnetic insulating spacer layers. The FM layers are denoted from bottom to top as L1, L2, L3, $\cdots$. In all models, the length along the $x$-axis, width along the $y$-axis, and thickness along the $z$-axis of each FM layer, nonmagnetic insulating spacer, and heavy-metal substrate are respectively equal to $500$ nm, $50$ nm and $1$ nm, where the FM layer L1 is attached to the heavy-metal substrate.

In the $N$-layer SAF racetracks ($N\geq2$), the neighboring FM layers are antiferromagnetically exchange-coupled through their FM/Spacer/FM interfaces. The magnetization in each FM layer is perpendicular to the racetrack plane due to the high perpendicular magnetic anisotropy (PMA), while the magnetization in neighboring FM layers are antiparallel due to the interlayer AFM exchange coupling. The Dzyaloshinskii-Moriya interaction (DMI) in each FM layer leads to the tilt of magnetization near the edge of the racetrack.

In our numerical simulations we explicitly consider $N$-layer skyrmions with $N=1,2,3,4$.
We assume that the relaxed magnetization distributions of FM layers L1 and L3 are almost pointing along the $+z$-direction, while those of FM layers L2 and L4 are almost pointing along the $-z$-direction. The background magnetization directions determine the skyrmion number of the magnetic skyrmion in each FM layer. The skyrmion number equals $1$ in the FM layers L1 and L3, while it equals $-1$ in the FM layers L2 and L4. The total skyrmion number $Q_{\text{tot}}$ of the $N$-layer skyrmion is $N$ modulo $2$; namely, $Q_{\text{tot}}=1,0,1,0$ for $N=1,2,3,4$, respectively (see Section 2.3 for details).

At the initial state, magnetic skyrmions are first created and relaxed at the position of $x=100$ nm, $y=25$ nm. With regard to the driving current injection scheme, we consider a confined current-perpendicular-to-plane (CPP) geometry. Namely, a charge current flows through the heavy-metal substrate in the $+x$-direction, which is converted into a spin current polarized along the $+y$-direction perpendicularly injected into the FM layer L1, due to the spin Hall effect. The magnetic skyrmion in the FM layers L1 is driven by the vertical spin current, while the other magnetic skyrmions in FM layers L2, L3, and L4 move accordingly due to the interlayer AFM exchange coupling between each adjacent FM layer. It should be noted that, for comparison purpose, we also simulate the straightforward case of unconfined CPP geometry with the bilayer SAF racetrack, where the spin current is injected into all FM layers, neglecting the presence of the insulating spacer.
